Introduction to Probability The even events are 2, 4 and 6 and these are mutually exclusive, so 𝑃 2 ∪ 4 ∪ 6 = 𝑃 2 + 𝑃 4 + 𝑃 6 = 3 6 = 1 2 Let 𝐴 = {2,4,6} and 𝐵 = {1,2,3} and these are not mutually exclusive, so 𝑃 𝐴 ∪ 𝐵 = 𝑃 𝐴 + 𝑃 𝐵 − 𝑃 𝐴 ∩ 𝐵 = 1 2 + 1 2 − 1 6 = 5 6 Summary 𝑃 𝐴 ∩ 𝐵 = 𝑃 𝐴 + 𝑃 𝐵 − 𝑃(𝐴 ∪ 𝐵) 𝑃 𝑒1 ∪ 𝑒2 ∪ ⋯ ∪ 𝑒𝑁 = 𝑃 𝑒1 + 𝑃 𝑒2 + ⋯ 𝑃(𝑒𝑁) Introduction to Probability Concept Formula Union 𝐴 ∪ 𝐵 Intersection 𝐴 ∩ 𝐵 Empty Set (disjoint) A ∩ 𝐵 = ∅ Sample Space A ∪ 𝐴 𝐶 = Ω Inclusion-Exclusion 𝐴 ∪ 𝐵 = 𝐴 + 𝐵 − 𝐴 ∩ 𝐵Examples Example Someone is interested in how often they eat ice cream, but unfortunately they only have data relating to the weather as well. Historically, the following facts are true: 1. The probability of rain on any day is 1/4 2. It rains and the person eats ice with probability 1/10 3. The probability that it rains or the person eats ice cream is 1/3 What is the probability the person eats ice cream? If 𝐴 = {1,2,3, … 16} and 𝐵 are all the positive numbers that perfectly divide by 3, what is |𝐴 ∩ 𝐵|? 2. If 𝐴 = {1,2,3, … 16}, 𝐵 are all the numbers that divide by 3, and 𝐶 are the numbers that divide 5 what is |𝐴 ∩ 𝐵 ∩ 𝐶|? 3. If I pick two numbers from 𝐴 = {1,2,3, … 16}, what is the probability that at least one divides 3? Introduction to Probability Solutions 1. We need the set 𝐵 = {3,6,9, … }. Then 𝐴 ∩ 𝐵 = {3,6,9,12,15} 2. We also need the set 𝐶 = {5,10,15 … }. Then 𝐴 ∩ 𝐵 ∩ 𝐶 = {15}. 3. Number of pairs in {1,2,3, … 16} is 16 2 . The number of pairs with no divisors of three is 11 2 so 𝑃 at least 1 divisor of three = 1 − 11 2 16 2 = 13 24 Introduction to Probability
